byline.contributor: Thomas Erdbrink reported from Tehran, Sewell Chan from London, and David E. Sanger from Washington. Somini Sengupta contributed reporting from the United Nations, and Rick Gladstone from New York.
byline.original: By THOMAS ERDBRINK, SEWELL CHAN and DAVID E. SANGER

abstract: Iran accepts invitation to participate in negotiations on ending Syrian conflict, joining nations that include United States and Saudi Arabia, which once sought to bar Iran from influencing Syria's future; invitation, coming after historic nuclear agreement, represents first time United States has diplomatically engaged Iran on Syria issue; Iran's inclusion in talks points to both changing dynamic of Syrian war and Iran's emergence from marginalization by America.
lead_paragraph: Russia has urged the inclusion of representation from Tehran in the Syrian civil war discussions, which will resume in Vienna on Friday.

headline.main: After a U.S. Shift, Iran Has a Seat at Talks on War in Syria
headline.print_headline: In U.S. Shift, Iran Has Seat at Syria Talks

snippet: Russia has urged the inclusion of representation from Tehran in the Syrian civil war discussions, which will resume in Vienna on Friday.
